awd_titl_txt: CCRI: ENS: Enhancing a Millimeter-Wave Massive MIMO Platform to Support the 5G V2X Networking and Automotive Sensing Research Community
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal aims to develop an open-source platform called M3 to facilitate research in 5G vehicular networking and automotive sensing. M3 enables experimental research on millimeter-wave (mmWave) technologies--the cornerstone for 5G wireless communication and automotive radar sensing.  mmWave radio/radar electronically steerable directional beams, generated by large antenna arrays, as communication/sensing medium.  Programmability is critical for mmWave experimental research, especially in real-time vehicular networking/sensing. Yet, to date, programmable mmWave devices are either too costly, or lack a reasonably-sized antenna array which is critical for real-time beam-steering operations. M3 will fill this gap with a low-cost software radio/radar featuring a large antenna array.  By designing a novel radio/radar architecture, M3 brings the per-node cost down by an order of magnitude, and increases the phased-array size by an order of magnitude, compared with the state-of-the-art.  The research team will deploy an open-access experimental testbed on the UCSD campus comprised of the M3 radios/radars. The researchers will also bring M3 to the broader research community, through online Q&A forum, hands-on workshops/tutorials, remote access, and hardware loans/replication services. 

This proposal aims to develop a programmable open-source massive Multiple-Input/Multiple-Output (MIMO) millimeter-wave (mmWave) platform called M3 to facilitate experimental research in 5G vehicular networking and automotive sensing. The project comprises three major research thrusts: (i) Develop software/firmware to enable a partially programmable 802.11ad mmWave radio with 288-element phased-array, allowing users to reconfigure the codebook entries and beam patterns, and access real-time per-beam channel state information (CSI). (ii) Develop a mmWave massive MIMO software-radio, comprising 4 radio frequency (RF) chains and 144 antenna elements in total. The software radio will integrate the OpenAirInterface 5G physical layer and core network stack. (iii) Develop a programmable MIMO mmWave phased-array radar, with 4 RF chains and 144 antenna elements, used for exploring high-resolution automotive sensing.  M3's cost is an order of magnitude lower compared with the state-of-the-art mmWave software-radio, but its phased-array is an order of magnitude higher.  The surprisingly low cost is attributed to a novel radio architecture design, which repurposes a commodity phased-array antenna as a programmable phased-array.  This project will bring M3 to the broader research community through hands-on workshops/tutorials, and provide user services including hardware loans, replication, and restricted remote access to a testbed comprised of M3 radios.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focuses on developing an open-source platform called M-Cube to facilitate experimental research in millimeter-wave (mmWave) vehicular networking and automotive sensing.  The project represents a collaborative effort between four faculty members covering a diverse set of expertise, spanning wireless network protocols, FPGA firmware, digital and RF, as well as mmWave phased arrays.

The intellectual merits of the project are reflected in 4 major milestones:

(1) Designing and prototyping the M-Cube mmWave MIMO software radio. The PI team has completed the design and implementation of the M-Cube platform, which transforms a commodity 60 GHz mmWave radio into a versatile software radio/radar (Fig. 1). This innovation reduces costs by nearly 30 times and increases the phased array antenna size by over 10 times compared to existing platforms. This work was recognized with the Best Paper Award at ACM MobiCom, a leading conference in wireless systems and mobile computing. The team further enhanced M-Cube with a 28 GHz phased array in collaboration with industry partners.

(2) Establishing a mmWave vehicle-to-everything (V2X) experimental testbed. Using M-Cube, the PI team has constructed a mmWave V2X testbed on the UCSD campus (Fig. 2).  The testbed consists of a modified version of the M-Cube nodes, which enables microscopic investigation of the mmWave V2X channel and the link.  Through testbed measurement, the team debunked some common misperceptions of mmWave V2X networks, and suggested ways to realize efficient and reliable mmWave networks under high mobility.

(3) Developing a novel mmWave MIMO radar with a massive array of phased arrays. The PI team designed HybRadar, a novel mmWave radar architecture featuring a hybrid beamforming antenna which consists of an array of phased arrays. The hybrid architecture offers similar performance with commercial MIMO radar, while using only a small number of RF chains, thus reducing the hardware complexity and cost. The team has demonstrated the effectiveness of this design by exploring new use cases in radar point cloud generation and fast radar scanning using directional beams.

(4) Designing and implementing NeuroRadar, a low-power neuromorphic radar hardware platform for low-power wireless sensing applications.  NeuroRadar follows a neuromorphic architecture that jointly designs the analog sensing hardware and neuromorphic signal processing.  Prototype implementation and extensive experiments have verified NeuroRadar’s capability to empower the resource-constrained Internet of Things (IoT) devices to perform low-power smart sensing.

(5) Using M-Cube to explore novel research use cases in mmWave sensing. The team has leveraged the M-Cube software-defined radio/radar to explore novel applications in mmWave sensing, including MVDNet, a radar-lidar fusion for automotive perception, and Mosaic, a model-driven framework to enable Non-Line-of-Sight (NLoS) mmWave sensing.

 

The broader impacts of the project are reflected in the following dissemination, outreach and educational activities:

(1) Dissemination and Collaboration. The PI team has distributed the M-Cube software radio to the research community through open-source sharing, free equipment loans and paid fabrication services. To date, researchers from more than 16 institutions in the US and EU have acquired around 36 M-Cube replicas to explore the frontier of mmWave communication and sensing. The PI team has been providing technical support to these users through detailed documentation, online meetings, tutorials, and Q&A sessions.

(2) M-Cube User Workshop. The PI Team held an M-Cube User Workshop on the UCSD campus in 2023, with around 18 in-person attendees and 6 online. The lead researchers presented hands-on instructions to the users for setting up the M-Cube software radio and using it to implement new communication or sensing algorithms. The workshop participants also presented their work-in-progress in order to foster new collaboration opportunities.

(3) Publications and Open-Source Releases. The outcomes from the project have been published and presented as full papers or demos in prestigious research venues including ACM MobiCom, MobiSys, IMWUT, SenSys, IEEE INFOCOM, etc. The project has also led to multiple open-source releases, including hardware schematics, FPGA firmware, machine learning models for mmWave sensing, ray tracing models for mmWave V2X channel modeling, generative models for synthetic mmWave sensing data generation, etc.  

(4) Industry Engagement. The project outcomes have been presented to multiple industry partners affiliated with UCSD’s Center for Wireless Communications (CWC) through the CWC annual review and annual San Diego 5G&Beyond Forum. The industry outreach inspired multiple collaborative projects and joint publications.

(5) Educational Impact. The project has cultivated a new workforce in the areas of mmWave communication, networking and sensing. Four PhD students and one postdoc scholar have been involved in various components in this project and stretched their skill sets across multiple disciplines. Among them, two became faculty members in renowned universities. Two female undergraduate students have also been actively participating in the FPGA implementation and were inspired to continue their graduate studies in related areas.
